head.title: List of deaths on eight-thousanders - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

div.div: From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
Jump to: navigation, search

td.span: This article needs additional citations for verification. Please help improve this article by adding citations to reliable sources. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed. (June 2011)

div.p: The eight-thousanders are the fourteen mountains that rise more than 8,000 metres (26,247 ft) above sea level; they are all in the Himalayan and Karakoram mountain ranges.
This is a list of mountaineers who have died on these mountains.

div.div: Six of the fourteen summits of the eight-thousanders (Manaslu, Shishapangma, Cho Oyu, Lhotse, Mt. Everest and Makalu).
North face of Mount Everest.

div.p: Mount Everest has been host to a large number of tragedies, with deaths occurring almost every year since its first ascent. The most notable occurred in 1922, 1970, 1974 and 1996. You can view the complete list of people who died climbing Mount Everest here.
div.div: This sports-related list is incomplete; you can help by expanding it.

tr.td: possible altitude sickness aggravated by high blood pressure
Died during descent from exhaustion. He could not make it down after discovering a cache of gear and food he had left on the mountain had been raided and died near Camp 3
Died during descent. His body remains 100m below the summit on the north face
Fall from 8 500 m to 6 700 m during the descent of the Hornbein couloir by skiing
Exposure. Sharp had been passed by 40 other climbers heading for the summit who made no attempt at a rescue. Sharp died under a rock overhang known as "Green Boots Cave"
Altitude sickness (member of the Discovery Channel expedition)
Dr. Sean Egan died after leaving Everest's base camp on his way to a lower altitude, suffering from a respiratory infection. Then it's believed he suffered a cardiac arrest
Died during his sleep at base camp. He worked as a sound recordist for a French expedition
Fall during an attempt to descend the Hornbein couloir with snowboard (age 23)
Fall attempting to rescue his wife (recovered in 1999 by the "Irvine and Mallory" expedition)

In 1988 Slovaks climbed in alpine style and without oxygen in attempt to scale Lhotse and then Mt Everest through southwest face in one go. After scaling Lhotse at night, expedition successfully scaled Mt Everest the next day but all died on descent in snow storm
Died on descent in snow storm
Died on descent in snow storm
Died on descent in snow storm
Capt Vijay Pal Singh Negi (Indian Army)
[26][63][73] Year and cause of death differ according to different sources
